reviewText:
This game is not perfect. In fact, its story is quite predictable. If you can put aside that the mystery isn't REALLY a mystery and more of a puzzle, then you will enjoy this game.

If you, like me, love watching arbitrary sliders go up for acting like a Lannister, you will enjoy this game. If you had a good, or at least not-awful time in High School, chances are you will enjoy this game.

It's not amazing, it doesn't have tons of depth. But it does have a lot of replayability, and the story it tells is interesting no matter what angle you come at it with, even if you want your Player Character to be a delinquent to a Model Citizen.

Just don't click fast. The one bug is that clicking fast will cause text to not show up, or skip a scene entirely.

Honestly, sell some trading cards and pick it up for change. You definately have worse ways to spend your time.

reviewText:
This story was short, predictable, and easy. Sad, because I liked a few other stories from Choice of Games and would usually want to replay them. But not this one.

First off, the characters' personalities barely had depth. No one was complex, which pretty much guaranteed my lack of attachments towards the characters. I didn't feel anything when making choices or reading because I couldn't relate to any of them. They were stereotypical to a fault.

There were also a few inconsistencies in the story. For example I was holding a job, yet the father of the protagonist said that he was the only one making money if the mom lost her job... and then the game suggested that I had too many things to do, so I had to drop something. I ended up dropping the job since it didn't seem like it had any real significance to the story. The cash I made didn't have any bearing to the game at all. What was the point of getting a job if it was barely acknowledged?

(spoiler) It also all just seemed so convenient to take down the villains, like how the protagonist just *happened* to find confidential tax information by doing some internet research, of all ways. Thing is, taxes aren't public unless the protagonist was some kind of elite hacker, but the game didn't make any mention of that. Also, students would not be normally suspicious about a teacher's salary and a nice house unless they had real reason to care or had it out for them. As for the villains, they barely had any chemistry at all. Their partnership was barely just a thread. People who commit tax fraud and brainwash people together would have a more familiar relationship, no?

Anyway this story has potential, but my impression is that it gave the bare minimum and it's still not complete. Even the endings could've been a bit more expanded upon to at least instill some satisfaction on the choices I've made, but it didn't.

reviewText:
Astonishingly poor. Very lazy and formulaic writing. While the author is mechanically literate and capable of basic plot planning, it reads like a condescending impassionate account of a middle aged person who is struggling with both remembering what those wacky tasteless dumb teenagers are supposed to be like and not falling asleep from the lack of any genuine interest in the subject matter. Needless to say, anything anyone might consider exciting about being a teenager is presented clinically at best. Often it's, again, condescending to a degree that is irksome even to someone who isn't a teenager anymore simply by the virtue of empathy. Which just makes you wonder who exactly was supposed to be the target audience of this work. Who is supposed to enjoy this oversimplified mockery of teenage life and why? I can only imagine perhaps pre-teens actually getting excited over this glimpse simply due to the fact that they're the only ones who might not know better and not realize just how hilariously fake it is.

There is very little to enjoy in this from any perspective. Every plot element is sterile, predictable and pragmatic. The way it's delivered it could as well have been about financial bookkeeping rather than magic, friendship or romance. There is no feeling to anything. There is absolutely no subtlety. Certain events and scenes are absurdly blunt and cheesy, serving as the only real source of amusement together with some silly action choices here and there. There is even a blatantly obvious self-insert character. I honestly don't know how much mindnumbing is necessary to be able to take any of this seriously. I certainly couldn't.

... And then I got an ending where my character ended up being a permanently confused mentally impaired couch potato incapable of coherent thought or perception. Which has left me with very strange feelings. I mean, don't get me wrong, I'm all for depressing endings that punish me for acting unwisely, which I absolutely have, but if you try to match this to the rest of the game which is absolutely impossible to take seriously... it just doesn't work. You can't just make me respect your story in one swift vindictive move. I mean, this ending is actually the most, or rather the only daring unexpected plot device in the whole story and how dark and depressing it is only makes it even more absurd and hilarious. It doesn't help that it's possibly a punishment only for my very last action and it's hard to say with certainity if that's the case. It's really hard to describe just how out of place and how big of a mismatch in tone this feels, but I certainly found it noteworthy so there you go anyway.


So yeah. This simply won't do. I can't recommend this to anyone for any reason. Especially not to fans of Veronica Mars, from which this work... tries to... take inspiration... sort of. Unless you want to see what a fanfiction of a cool drama series would look like if it was in the accounting book genre.

reviewText: Quirky, awesome branching of storylines, multiple endings, decent writing, and engaging.\n\nPsy High is really quite fun if you grew up with Choose Your Own Adventure novels growing up (like myself). In terms of a text adventure, it doesn't compare being that progression through the story is more linear than an open world of TAs of old. BUT, the writing draws you in, the characters are believable and interactions are fun. I found myself wanting to boot up another game or two just to see what happens if I had chosen my path differently. Which by the looks of it, and knowing how these sort of games" work; there seems to be a good amount of variability in story if you make different choices. I failed my first attempt
date: in the sense that I didn't get a perfectly happy ending. But because it was just a whole lot of fun reading the story and playing the game
recommended: I'm plesantly surprised to say this game gets my stamp of approval.\n\n8/10"

reviewText:
Psy High is a solid piece of interactive fiction.  Good, and worth full price, though not _great_.  I found it an enjoyable way to pass an hour and a half, and may replay it in future.

For those who haven't played a Choice Of game before, it's basically the natural evolution of Choose your Own Adventure Books, a few decades on.  They're MUCH more refined than the CYOA books of the 80s, though.  They're Wolfenstein: the New Order to the original Wolfenstein 3D.

You're given a short novel in which most important decisions are up to you, the reader.  Whether the plot twist you decide on succeeds depends on the choices you've made so far - staying in character is rewarded, while out of character actions are less likely to work.

The character in question is the sum of your past choices.  If at every turning point in the story so far, you've chosen to act like a selfish loner, don't expect to be able to successfully give an inspirational speech to rally others to your side.  I've you've chosen sports over academics whenever you've been able to, you'll almost certainly succeed at physical challenges (or those involving swaying the sports team or its fans) while not necessarily having a good chance of passing that crucial history test.

The story of Psy High is exactly as described.  If it were a live-action TV show, it wouldn't be (much) out of place on a DIsney afternoon line-up, or playing just before Charmed or Supernatural.

The writing is good enough to have often made me forget I was playing a game without graphics.  The characters are your usual high school stereotypes, but handled competently.  Choices have a satisfying level of consequence, but the game seldom presents you with unfixable mistakes.

In my playthrough, there were some strange jumps in the story near the end.  I can't tell if this was a deliberate editing choice, or if a few 'pages' were missing in error.  Though the jumps were a little jarring, I was still able to follow the story.  (Imagine an episode of 24 not accounting for fifteen minutes of the 24 hours, near the end.)

There were two pretty noticeable weaknesses to the story - first, the central plot was completely predictable from just a few minutes in.  A mystery to the reader, it certainly wasn't.

Second, although I think I chose the 'main' romance (kudos to Choice of Games for providing tons of tasteful choices for all preferences, as usual) it still felt pretty tacked on - almost as if most of the scenes and details had been added after the rest of the game was written.

Worth full price, but best for younger players (12-16).

reviewText: Kids with magic powers. Highschool-drama. Occult happenings and witchcraft versus worrying about what to wear to the prom and which of the girls (or boys) you wanna date. Not the worst Choice-title
date: but not my favourite either - might be worth a shot if you are into highschool-settings and tired of typical high fantasy or science-fiction. Was okay for one "play"-through."

reviewText: I'd like to point out that I really enjoy choose your own adventure games. I really enjoyed Choice of Robots, which led me to play Psy High; they're from the same company.\nI really wanted to like this story, but I just couldn't. Too much of this story was obviously borrowed from other ideas. Lots of games and literature borrow ideas from pre-existing stories, but it becomes a problem when nothing new is added to the borrowed material.\nA teenaged investigator? Veronica Mars, anyone? A bunch of teenagers with magical abilities? Okay, there's lots of things you could take that from, but I got a Secret Circle vibe from this. The big one is a conspiracy happening within a high school to make students better." If this isn't an idea from the movie Disturbing Behavior
date: then I'd like to know what did inspire it. No

reviewText: I love reading and I think CYOAs are a great way to immerse yourself in a story. But this is the lamest CYOA I've ever bought from Steam. This game is full of generic, forgettable characters and the writing is very dull. The writer somehow manages to take something cool and exciting and make it UNexciting and dull. Maybe making fun things suck is her superpower? In addition to that, in this story you go to school in what is practically San Francisco with Gay Pride Week and all. The writer specifies that you are happy to be there - as is everyone else in the story - and that if this or that happened, such as two boys going to the prom with each other, neither you nor anyone else would even blink because you and everyne else in this story supports that. I'm not being insulting to any LGBT people but come on. People are individuals and when a writer stupidly introduces an extremely divisive subject like homosexuality (or abortion or illegal immigration or any other unpleasant real-life subject) and tells the player how they feel about the topic they stupidly destroy the immersion if the player's opinion is different. So this game sucks both in my opinion and as a CYOA.

Okay, I've not read through all of this yet, but I've gone through the entire demo then a while later bought the game. Personally, I like this, especially when it comes to the choices, though I do wish the choices were a bit more customizable. That aside, there's something I personally find funny when it comes to the genders and names of some characters (not all, but some) depending on your gender and sexual preference.

Some characters stay the same gender they are when first introduced, but others are actually changed, as are their names to basically the same thing, just a variant to match the gender. (Minor spoiler alert) I kinda wish it wasn't Carl/Carla or Tyler/Taylor, it would've been better, in my opinion, if the variants were of the same personality and powers, but different appearances (clothes and physical appearance) as well as different names. Hide some of the cliched cheesiness of it.

Overall, I do enjoy this, but some improvements could've easily been made.

Disclaimer:  I'm biased because I went to college with the author (and others at Choice of Games).  That said, this was fun.  Relive the classic scenes from high school (and movies about high school) - the pep rally, the prom, the surprise exam - and address them with not only the benefit of hindsight, but also super-powers.   Unlike most superhero games, however, your powers don't involve flying, generating force fields, or blowing things up.  You have clairvoyance and maybe telepathy.  Those can be useful, but only in combination with social skills.  Used poorly, they can isolate you and mark you as a freak.  Which means it reallly is like high school, only for bigger stakes.

This in my opinion is a great text game and play alot of text games and this might be my favorite.

I will say it's not perfect like the romance options are really the basic's in most games with romancable options. you have the crush, the childhood friend and the best friend(also pretty much any romance anime go for the same things). These all have in my opinion not much effort. By this i mean it's there but doesn't seem like there is much thought into it. They just pretty much hint that they have a crush on you or just say it in the middle of something with no actual effort.

But everything else about this game I like. I definetly reccomend it for those that like the story lines but if you are like me (I got it for the romance and I like most text games romance choices) then I do not reccomend it for that reason.
tHIS IS A BEAUTIFUL GAME A WOMDERFUL STORY
I enjoyed my first playthrough, quick question, can you get at any of the teachers?

I went into this game expecting it to be like Surviving High School or Cause of Death. You know before EA thought it was best to remove those games from the App store. Anyway, it's not at all like those games, but i actually enjoyed it. It's completely story driven and even though it's a text adventure, I really felt as if my choices made an impact and that i was a high school detective. And besides its only $2.99 and available for PC and Mac. If your a fan of huge gameplay then this game may not be for you. But if your a fan of interesting stories, and are tolerant of text adventures, then this is a must buy. Rebecca Slitt has a very creative mind and if she makes another one like this or even a sequel then i hope she puts in at least music, and pictures so we can really create our own character.

Even if I could swallow the fairly amateurish writing, I got a scripting error after one of my choices (something about hide and seek?) and now when I try to load the game, all I can look at are my stats.  It won't let me progress any farther.  Might have tried to see it to the end, but can't now.  Oh well, save your cash.
really good, wouldn't buy it if u have reading difficulty or if u wanna see the tiddy

I love it. You can romance 4 girls in all and theres an achievement for dating 3 of them at once. What i figured out was that that means cheating on 3 people, not a polyamorous relationship like I had hoped

A Lovely Read
My oppinion may be slightly biast due to my passion for young adult novels

It took me roughly five hours to complete this (game?), and during those five hours I was hooked; Seriously I couldn't stop playing. The story may have been slightly shallow and predictible (dont expect a master peice here) yet I still found it enjoyable to read and (play?) through, never the less its entertaining as hell. Sell a few steam cards and buy this game, even if you are only slightly inclined towards young adult novels or choose your own adventure games, because trust me it makes a nice read.
I liked the story a lot. I do wish I could create" a character and see things.\n\nBut
recommended: this type of game is a sort of guilty pleasure of mine and I am happy with anything I can get. lmao"

reviewText: Game is OK.  One problem game may be a little long for one play through per sitting.  How do you save game?

I've previously played Tin Star by Choice games and LOVED it. I totally reccommend it to anyone who's bought any of their other games.

Anyway, onto Psy High. It is definately not the worse interactive novel I have ever played, but not the best. I enjoyed all of the 5-6 hours I played it, however, and I believe I will play it again. It's an easy read, with a choice on every page but maybe a dozen. The writing is simple but not insulting, and the characters you interact with aren't bad. There's some suggestion with teenage stereotypes, but that's mostly directed towards you, and the path/dialouge options, which can be very direct and hand-holdy - though it isn't BAD, necessarily. I'm coming from playing Tin Star, which is much different and more detailed.

Anyway, the long and short of it is that the game IS good and is pretty original. It's another high school setting, but the story is pretty interesting. There's the option to be straight, gay, bisexual, and the ability to cause a lot of trouble around school by various avenues. It's worth the 2.99 I paid for it. If you want an interesting, homey/casual little adventure that takes place in a magical Massechusettes town, go ahead and pick the game up.

I thought that this game, while not one of the best Choice of Games has done, was an excellent story. It was well contained and wrapped up nicely, giving me the completle feelling. I would recomend this to any fans of CYOA games. 8 out of 10 in my book guys. Keep up the good work.
awesome game, story, makes you anxious in the right moments, I personally loved

For three bucks it is a good game!! It was very interesting and i did enjoy playing and discovering all the rewards of options i chose. That being said, as much as i really liked it it could have been a lot better. it felt like a story that i would write in middleschool, trying to shove all my fictional and logical ideas and detail into one very short story. There was almost no room for character development which was a huge dissapointment. For example i had the option to date a cgharacter in the story but had no option to learn more about them other than the fact i had a crush on them appearently. The story would benifit very much with extra revisions but in general it was a good story filled with romance, fantasy, and desision making which i love in any game or work of literature.
Sceptical at first but this is an incredible game.
Had to play the whole thing through in one sitting, I thoroughly enjoyed it. I look forward to my next couple of play throughs!

I can't wait to play more games like this. This game was cute, exciting, and really fun to go through. There are so many paths and I felt like i could create exactly the kind of person I was in school and you can too. I am terrible at reviews but definitely give this a chance.
Enjoyable.

The concept definitely seems extremely cheesy and low-brow. And hey, maybe it is, and maybe this game isn't for people who think they're too good for high school teen stories. Honestly, when I first saw the tagline Teen supernatural mystery!"
date: I was a bit put off
helpfulPercent: in spite of the setting and concept which would normally be regaled to the young adult bargain bin at Barnes and Nobles (Does B&N even have bargain bins?) the game is
votesTotal: very fun for those who are willing to not take themselves or CYOA games too seriously
votesFunny: and just engage in a bit of a simple and cliche story.\n\nMechanically
commentsCount: it's a bit above average compared to other Choice of Games stuff. There's multiple "morality stats"
column16: each one being played out at plenty of different points throughout the game. You have several "ability stats"
column17: which do directly influence your success at various choices - It is even possible to "lose" the game if you attempt to do something drastic that you don't have the ability level to do.\n\nStory and character wise
column19: it's a bit simple and cliche
column21: but the characters are charming and engaging in spite of this. The most important thing for me
column24: unlike several other "Choice" of Games titles
column25: this one actually has significantly different endings depending on the choices you've made throughout the game. I won't spoil what these are
column27: but it is refreshing to see a CYOA where what you choose to do actually has impact
column28: rather than just "(Character Name) will remember this." (They never do.)\n\nOverall: 8/10
column29: don't play if you're too stuck-up to enjoy something a bit less cerebral than other CoG titles."

reviewText: Aha! This was a very nice story. I took parts of who I was in High School and who I am today with of course a few choices a little exagerrated. Like how I was definitely in Drama class but I never actually participated in a play.\n\nAnyways I really liked the writing and found myself laughing at some of the situations as being very clever of me"."
I played four hours of this and multiple stories because IT'S FUN. BUY IT.

Compared to other games of this kind (Tin Star, Choice of Robots, Choice of Broadsides, Zombie Exodus ...) it's extremely childish. If you're past the making out with cute girls and being a popular jock" phase
date: it might not ravish you. Nonetheless
recommended: you keep reading and spend a quite alright time."

reviewText:
Sure, it's a bit cliche, but this interactive novel is quite a bit of fun.
Quite a number of other reviews I've read are saying that the major problem with this one is the characters and the length. Sure, this one is quite a bit shorter than other titles in the Choice Of Games collection, but it does have a lower price tag then the others and I feel like I got what I paid for.
I do agree with the others when they say that they didn't feel as connected to the characters as they would in the other CoG titles, but I didn't mind. With a short one-off story like this, it worked for me.
All in all, pretty good story. If you haven't read/played a game like this before, I'd recommend jumping onto a couple of the other Choice of Games titles before coming over to this one, but it is worth it!

Mediocre all around, plot, characters, etc. The kids having psychic powers was barely relevant to the plot. Easily the worst of the three Choice of Games interactive stories I've read (Community College Hero and Choice of Robots are both recommended).
awesome game, story, makes you anxious in the right moments, I personally loved

reviewText:
I've read through it once and I found it to be a really fun story although not groundbreaking and some parts were freaking rushed. Some scenes really needed more detail and the characters should have become more memorable throughout the story, sadly they didn't. I didn't really mind the absence of graphics and music or soundeffects. It still was a nice experience.

In general I really appreciated the tons of options one could choose from throughout the story, although some sounded very much alike. It weren't answers that could lead one to either victory or dead randomly ... the outcome made sense. I've played enough interactive stories (visual novels) to be able to tell that this isn't always the case.

Erm... What I thought was a bit off, was the money... Did one only have to save it up for the prom? How superficial. What I also didn't like was, that I really couldn't understand how the stats would change. Sometimes I chose options I thought would boost my magic stat for example... But it either didn't increase or it dropped. Whuuuuut. Maybe my character just slacked off too much, don't know.

What's more? Last but not least I liked the general look and feel. I don't know if the UI of the game is totally basic or not or if it's just considered basic but I liked it. One could check the stats and the achievements and oh well... it was nice.

So... I'd definitely recommend it. I mean, the story is nothing out of the ordinary but it is nice enough so it's definitely a game worth purchasing, even more so, since it's really at a fair price.
